title: Cockfosters
text:
Cockfosters is a suburb of <a href="north%20London">north London</a> to the east of <a href="Chipping%20Barnet">Chipping Barnet</a>, lying partly in the <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Enfield">London Borough of Enfield</a> and partly in the <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Barnet">London Borough of Barnet</a>. Before 1965, it was in the counties of <a href="Middlesex">Middlesex</a> and <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>.
Origins and popular attractions.
The name was recorded as far back as 1524 and is thought to be either the name of a family or that of a house which stood on <a href="Enfield%20Chase">Enfield Chase</a>. One suggestion is that it was "the residence of the cock forester (or chief forester)".
Of note in Cockfosters is <a href="Trent%20Park">Trent Park</a>, now a <a href="country%20park">country park</a>. <a href="Christ%20Church%2C%20Cockfosters">Christ Church, Cockfosters</a>, an <a href="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> <a href="evangelical">evangelical</a> church, was founded in 1839. <a href="Christ%20the%20King%2C%20Cockfosters">Christ the King, Cockfosters</a> (Vita et Pax), a <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a> church, was founded in 1930. The <a href="Piccadilly%20line">Piccadilly line</a> of the <a href="London%20Underground">London Underground</a> reached Cockfosters in 1933. The Cock Inn (formerly the Cock), off Cockfosters Road on Chalk Lane, opened in 1798.
Education.
<a href="Southgate%20School">Southgate School</a> is located on Sussex Way.
Trent C of E Primary School is located on Chalk Lane.
Theatre and the arts.
The <a href="Chickenshed">Chickenshed Theatre Company</a>, founded in 1975 in a <a href="chicken%20coop">chicken shed</a> before relocating to its current site, originated the concept of inclusive theatre.
Sport and leisure.
Cockfosters has a <a href="non-League%20football">non-League football</a> club, <a href="Cockfosters%20F.C.">Cockfosters F.C.</a>, which plays at the Cockfosters Sports Ground.
The <a href="Saracens%20F.C.">Saracens</a> used to play at Chase Side (also known as Clocktower Park); however, they are now based in <a href="Barnet%20Copthall">Hendon</a>. The ground is still used for <a href="Enfield%20F.C.">Enfield F.C.</a> training and for the Saracens' 'B' team, Saracens Storm. It is also used as Saracens Amateurs' training ground.
Cockfosters Cricket Club and Southgate Compton Cricket Club play at Chalk Lane on fields adjacent to Christ Church, either side of Cockfosters Bowling Club.
Trent Country Park covers approximately 320 hectares (791 acres, 1.2 sq mi) and features treetop <a href="adventure%20park">adventure park</a> <a href="Go%20Ape">Go Ape</a>.
Demographics.
Cockfosters has its own <a href="electoral%20ward">electoral ward</a> in the Enfield borough. The 2011 census of Cockfosters ward counted a population of 16,137. The ethnic composition was 73.7% <a href="Caucasian%20race">white</a> (51.7% <a href="British%20people">British</a>, 19.7% Other, 2.2% <a href="Irish%20people">Irish</a>), 13.5% <a href="Asians">Asian</a> (6.5% <a href="Indian%20people">Indian</a>), and 8% <a href="Black%20%28race%29">black</a> (2.9% <a href="African%20diaspora">African</a>). The most spoken foreign languages were <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a> and <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a>. Fifty per cent of the population were <a href="Christians">Christians</a>, with <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>s and <a href="Judaism">Jew</a>s forming 10% and 9% respectively. Of the 5,215 households, 3,219 resided in a <a href="house">whole house</a> or <a href="bungalow">bungalow</a>; 68.8% of home tenures were <a href="home%20ownership">owned</a>, with minorities of privately rented and socially rented homes. Of economically active people, 4.2% were unemployed. The <a href="median%20age">median age</a> was forty years. The part within the borough of Barnet is covered by the <a href="East%20Barnet">East Barnet</a> ward.
Culture.
"Cockfosters" is the name of a 2015 short-story collection by <a href="Helen%20Simpson%20%28author%29">Helen Simpson</a>. One of the short stories features a visit to "lost property" at <a href="Cockfosters%20tube%20station">Cockfosters Underground station</a>. The poet <a href="John%20Betjeman">John Betjeman</a>, who taught at <a href="Heddon%20Court%20School">Heddon Court School</a> in 1929–30, wrote "The Cricket Master" about his experiences there.
People.
The <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) for <a href="Enfield%20Southgate%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Enfield Southgate</a> from 2005 to 2017, <a href="David%20Burrowes">David Burrowes</a>, was born in Cockfosters. <a href="George%20Baillie%20Duncan">George Baillie Duncan</a> ministered at <a href="Christ%20Church%2C%20Cockfosters">Christ Church, Cockfosters</a>, and the cricketer <a href="Andrew%20Wingfield%20Digby">Andrew Wingfield Digby</a> was a <a href="curate">curate</a> there. <a href="Cameron%20McVey">Cameron McVey</a> grew up in Cockfosters. Other transient residents have included the footballers <a href="Tommy%20Docherty">Tommy Docherty</a> and <a href="George%20Eastham">George Eastham</a> and <a href="Dave%20Davies">Dave Davies</a> of the <a href="The%20Kinks">Kinks</a>. Professors <a href="John%20Stollery">John Stollery</a> and <a href="Ian%20Jacobs%20%28academic%29">Ian Jacobs</a> also grew up in Cockfosters.
Transport.
Two tube stations are located within Cockfosters:
<a href="London%20Buses">London Buses</a> routes <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20298">298</a>, <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20299">299</a>, <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20307">307</a>, <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20384">384</a>, <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20692">692</a>, <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20699">699</a>, <a href="London%20Buses%20route%20N91">N91</a> serve Cockfosters.
